executive_summary:
This engagement spanned two calls — an initial discovery/qualification call and a follow-up tailored demo — involving the rep and three prospect stakeholders: Thomas Wright (VP of Operations), Lisa Chang (Digital Transformation Lead), and Mark Johnson (CFO). Lisa had initially reached out to explore modernizing their 15-year-old production scheduling system. The conversations covered the prospect's current operational setup, the proposed platform's capabilities (including rush order handling, reporting, SAP integration), pricing (approximately $500-600K+ year one, $80-100K annually thereafter), implementation timeline (4-6 months), and competitive positioning against CompetitorZ. The core tension throughout was between Lisa's push for digital transformation and Thomas's strong resistance to change.

Thomas was the dominant objector across both calls, consistently arguing that the current system works, the investment is unjustified, and the implementation risk is too high. He cited 28 years of manufacturing experience and a track record of stable operations to support his position. Lisa countered with arguments about competitive pressure, lost bids, board-mandated digital transformation evaluation, and potential efficiency gains (40% reduction in schedule change cycle time), but was unable to overcome Thomas's resistance. The rep handled objections professionally — proposing phased rollouts, pilot programs, reference customers, and live demos — but none of these approaches shifted Thomas's stance. Mark Johnson, the CFO, was largely observational, focused on understanding total cost but did not weigh in on the strategic merits.

The deal is effectively dead in the near term. By the end of the demo call, Thomas explicitly stated he cannot support moving forward, and Lisa acknowledged she lacks the authority to push the initiative through without Operations' buy-in. The engagement has been tabled, with Lisa indicating she will continue internal conversations but does not see movement in the short term. The rep offered to stay in touch should circumstances change.

key_moments.description: Thomas Wright declared early in the first call that the current system works and he is not convinced there is a problem to solve, setting the tone for the entire engagement.
key_moments.significance: This established Thomas as the primary blocker and signaled that the deal would hinge on winning his support — which the rep was never able to achieve.

key_moments.description: The CFO calculated the total year-one investment at over $600K, and Thomas immediately framed it as spending half a million to replace something that isn't broken.
key_moments.significance: The cost conversation crystallized the value gap. Without a compelling ROI narrative that resonated with Thomas, the investment amount became ammunition for his resistance rather than a point of negotiation.

key_moments.description: Despite skepticism, Thomas agreed to attend the demo and specifically requested to see rush order rescheduling — a real-world scenario he cared about.
key_moments.significance: This was the closest the deal came to a breakthrough. Thomas engaged on his own terms, giving the rep an opportunity to prove value in a scenario that mattered to Operations.

key_moments.description: Lisa revealed the company lost two bids to competitors with better lead times, but Thomas reattributed the losses to pricing, not lead times.
key_moments.significance: This exposed a fundamental disagreement between stakeholders about the business problem. The rep missed an opportunity to dig deeper into the lost bids with data, which could have been a powerful value proof point.

key_moments.description: Thomas definitively stated he cannot support moving forward, and Lisa conceded she does not have the authority to override him, effectively killing the deal.
key_moments.significance: This confirmed that the real decision-maker for this purchase is Thomas (or requires his alignment), and Lisa — the champion — does not have sufficient organizational power to advance the initiative alone.

action_items.action: Stay in periodic contact with Lisa Chang to monitor for changes in internal dynamics, board pressure, system failures, or competitive losses that could reopen the conversation.
Send a concise follow-up email thanking all three stakeholders, summarizing the demo findings, and leaving the door open — without being pushy.

Prepare a targeted ROI analysis using the prospect's specific data (overtime costs, lost bids, schedule change cycle times) that Lisa could use to build an internal business case if the conversation reopens.
Continue internal advocacy and gather more concrete data on competitive losses and operational inefficiencies to strengthen the business case for future discussions.
Identify whether the board's digital transformation mandate creates any timeline pressure or executive sponsor who could influence Thomas's position.

prospect_priorities: Operational stability and risk avoidance — Thomas's overriding concern is protecting current operations from disruption, and he views any system change as inherently risky.
Cost justification and ROI — Mark (CFO) focused immediately on total investment and ongoing costs, signaling that any future attempt must have a rock-solid financial business case.

Competitive positioning and modernization — Lisa is concerned about falling behind competitors who are digitizing and achieving better lead times, driven partly by a board mandate to evaluate digital transformation.
Minimal disruption to production teams — Thomas repeatedly emphasized that his team's time is better spent running production than participating in an implementation project.

Real-world proof over marketing promises — Thomas explicitly demanded realistic demonstrations and expressed deep distrust of vendor claims based on past negative experiences with software implementations.
concerns_to_address: The champion (Lisa) lacks sufficient authority and organizational influence to advance the deal without Operations buy-in, creating a structural blocker that no amount of product demonstration can overcome.

Thomas's resistance appears rooted in deeply held beliefs about change management risk from 28 years of experience — this is an emotional and philosophical objection, not just a rational one, and will require a different approach than feature demonstrations.

The CFO was largely passive and non-committal throughout both calls. His stance on the investment is unknown, and without his active support, even if Thomas were neutralized, the deal could still stall on financial grounds.

The rep never established a quantified cost of inaction — the manual workarounds, spreadsheet risks, overtime costs, and lost bids were mentioned by Lisa but never validated or dollarized in a way that created urgency.

There may be a higher-level executive sponsor (board level) driving the digital transformation mandate who was never engaged. The absence of executive sponsorship above Thomas left the champion exposed.

Thomas disputed Lisa's claim about lost bids being related to lead times, reattributing them to price. This unresolved internal disagreement about the root cause of business challenges undermines the case for change.
The prospect's SAP environment is on an older version, which could introduce hidden integration complexity and cost that was glossed over during the call.
